issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

comment.body:
tf_sentencepiece is already deprecated and no longer supported. The released binary package does not include M2 binary, so this error is expected.

You might be able to build tf_sentencepiece from scratch. This issue might be useful.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/367

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

`
```cmake -A -B ./build -DSPM_BUILD_TEST=ON -DSPM_ENABLE_SHARED=OFF```

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.

pull_request.title: Enable iOS builds
pull_request.body:
This PR allows to build sentencepiece for iOS platforms. To do so just do:
```
mkdir build
cd build 
cmake .. -G Xcode -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../cmake/ios.toolchain.cmake -DPLATFORM=OS64
cmake --build . --config Release
```

issue.title: Bug: can't co-exist with pytorch-lightning
issue.body:
I'm trying to train a T5 model with `transformers` library, which requires the `sentencepiece` library to tokenize sentence. But when I installed it with `pip install sentencepiece`, I can't import the `pytorch-lightning` library anymore. It yields 
* when `sentencepiece==0.1.5`,
```
Python 3.7.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct 26 2021, 06:08:21) 
[GCC 9.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pytorch_lightning
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:58] File already exists in database: google/protobuf/descriptor.proto
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:1401] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
  what():  CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
Aborted (core dumped)
```


* when `sentencepiece==0.1.8`
```
Python 3.7.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct 26 2021, 06:08:21) 
[GCC 9.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pytorch_lightning
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

I reported the same issue in `pytorch-lightning` [issues](https://github.com/PyTorchLightning/pytorch-lightning/issues/11663).

issue.title: Segmentation fault on Ubuntu with basic python test
issue.body:

Here is the [basic test](https://github.com/gretelai/gretel-synthetics/blob/7e73a3119e1f3cfb926918b81761c013e0d0d0d1/tests/test_tokenizers.py#L101) that is being run.

issue.title: Slow computing time using BPE+Seq2Seq model
issue.body:
Thanks for your excellent work! One thing I would like to check with you is that the model computing time difference between sentencepiece vs. normal tokenization method such as Keras tokenizer. Using a traditional tokenization method, the training time takes maybe 10 minutes. Using BPE, it does not take long to train the text corpus from scratch. However, the modeling time takes appr. 5 hours for one epoch. Did I do anything wrong when combining BPE + seq2seq model? Any comments? Thank you in advance!

You can view my code from the following links:

https://github.com/Lvby/amazon/blob/master/amazonFood.ipynb 
or
https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/Lvby/amazon/blob/master/amazonFood.ipynb

comment.body:
The model file is immutable, so we do not support modifying the model after training. However, the model file is just a serialized protobuf so it is technically possible to update the model (adding tokens) manually at-your-own-risk basis.

Please take a look at this thread.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

issue.title: SentencePieceProcessor.encode() breaks down special tokens that exist in vocabulary
issue.body:
Hi,
I am using the t5 sentencepice model:  `gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model`.
The `SentencePieceProcessor.encode()` function does _not_ seem to recognize the special tokens (e.g., `<pad>`,`</s>`), while these tokens do exist in the vocab.


```
gsutil cp gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model /tmp/
```

```python
import sentencepiece as spm
s = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='/tmp/sentencepiece.model')

# Check that EOS exists in the model vocab, get the token corresponding to EOS
s.IdToPiece(s.eos_id())
Out: '</s>'

# Encode EOS string to its id, it doesn't work, breaks it down to smaller pieces
s.encode('</s>')
Out: [3, 2, 87, 7, 3155]

s.IdToPiece([3, 2, 87, 7, 3155])
Out: ['▁', '<unk>', '/', 's', '>']
```

Am I using the wrong function to encode the text into ids?

comment.body: This is a FAQ. https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/667

issue.title: Creating tokenizer from counts file?
issue.body: Is there a way to create the tokenizer from the counts file? This would enable generating a tokenizer from extremely large corpuses feasible as we can use a Hadoop preprocessing step to create the word count statistics. This shouldn't change the correctness because, for languages like English, we don't consider subwords across word boundaries anyways.

issue.title: pkg-config file is broken when CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR is absolute
issue.body:
As per title: `CMakeLists.txt` has
```
set(prefix ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX})
set(exec_prefix "\${prefix}")
set(libdir "\${exec_prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}")
set(includedir "\${prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_INCLUDEDIR}")
```
and so can’t handle absolute paths in `CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR`. This leads to broken .pc files on NixOS in particular.

Identical to https://github.com/libjxl/libjxl/issues/1400 (fixed). See “[Concatenating paths when building pkg-config files](https://github.com/jtojnar/cmake-snips#concatenating-paths-when-building-pkg-config-files)” for a thorough discussion of the problem and a suggested fix, or [KDE’s extra-cmake-modules](https://invent.kde.org/frameworks/extra-cmake-modules/-/blob/master/modules/ECMGeneratePkgConfigFile.cmake#L166) for a simpler approach.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #772 from laurentsimon/feat/slsa3

Sign wheels in GitHub releases

pull_request.title: Sign wheels in GitHub releases
pull_request.body:
Hi,

I'm reaching out on behalf of the [Open Source Security Foundation (openssf.org)](https://openssf.org/). We work on improving the security of critical open source projects like yours. 

Together with [GitHub](https://github.blog/2022-04-07-slsa-3-compliance-with-github-actions/), we designed a free, easy-to-use method of code signing. It will help your users verify that your release wheels were built from your repository’s [workflow](https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/.github/workflows/wheel.yml) and not altered by anyone. It will make your project more secure against third-party tampering and attacks like [Codecov](https://about.codecov.io/apr-2021-post-mortem/) and [CTX](https://sockpuppets.medium.com/how-i-hacked-ctx-and-phpass-modules-656638c6ec5e).

This PR shows how to add this code signing to your workflow. You don’t have to be a cryptography expert or learn complicated tools and [verification](https://github.com/slsa-framework/slsa-verifier/blob/main/README.md#verification-of-provenance) is simple for your users.  

You can read more on the [SLSA blog](https://slsa.dev/blog/2022/06/slsa-github-workflows). Please reach out if you have any questions!

issue.title: Difficulty installing on M1 mac (solved)
issue.body:
Hi all just wanted to share this in case anyone else runs into it. I was having trouble installing sentencepiece on my M1 mac. Tried `pip install sentencepiece`, tried downloading, tried installing from source. Kept running into:
```  clang -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -Wunreachable-code -fno-common -dynamic -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -isysroot /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX12.sdk -I/Users/jvm/venv/include -I/opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.9/include/python3.9 -c src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx -o build/temp.macosx-12-arm64-cpython-39/src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.o -std=c++11 -mmacosx-version-min=10.9
  src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx:2809:10: fatal error: 'sentencepiece_processor.h' file not found
  #include <sentencepiece_processor.h>
           ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  1 error generated.
  error: command '/usr/bin/clang' failed with exit code 1
  error: subprocess-exited-with-error
```

Tried installing the c library from source, when I tried running `sudo update_dyld_shared_cache` I got a note that it was deprecated, and then couldn't seem to find the header file.

In the end all I needed to do to solve it was `brew install sentencepiece`. So might be ideal to add that to the documentation.

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

comment.body:
We can use '\t' as the constraint of the tokenization, though it is only used in unigram mode.


Here's the sample not using '\t'
```
>> import sentencepiece as spm
>>> with open('botchan.txt', 'r') as f:
...     lines = f.readlines()

>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines), model_prefix='m', vocab_size=2000)
>> .. snip
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁the']
```

Then insert '\t' to the places not to split. ('the' must not be one token')

```
>>> lines2 = [s.replace('the', 't\th\e') for s in lines]
>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines2), model_prefix='m2', vocab_size=2000)
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m2.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁t', 'h', 'e']
```

issue.title: Leftover "▁" characters after spm_decode
issue.body:
After running spm_decode v0.1.86 on the BPE-encoded output of neural machine translation,  special characters "▁" appear connecting some words. I assume that spm_decode should have removed them. Could you please explain why this is occurring and how I can fix it?

example:

before:

`▁The ▁film ▁service ▁calls ▁the ▁film ▁a ▁“ s imp ly ▁kn it ▁com edy ▁of ▁the ▁p ole ▁that ▁shows ▁the ▁un in hib ited ▁ra ge ▁of ▁destruction ▁of ▁children ▁without ▁thought ▁and ▁without ▁a ▁sense ▁of ▁ped agog ical ▁undert ones .”`

after:

`The film service calls the film a “simply▁knit comedy of the pole that shows the uninhibited rage of destruction of children without thought and without a sense of▁pedagogical▁undertones.”`

issue.title: Word based algorithm in SentencePiece is not being able to preserve some character in Devanagiri
issue.body:
The sentence piece provides four algorithm for training the tokenizer. BPE, char, unigram and word. Among these all are performing well however the BLEU score while testing on word based tokenization giving very bad result on test data. This is also the same case with huggingface BertWordPiece tokenizer.

I have tested it on Bodo text which is written in Devanagiri script. I hope this problem will be there in Hindi, Marathi or other Indian languages using Devanagiri scripts.

I have uploaded the tokenizer model file in my page if you need to verify https://github.com/sanjibnarzary/bodo-tokenizers

issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

comment.body:
v0.1.97 adds the option to emit ``<unk>`` instead of the original string.

Here is the example where feeding Japanese characters in English model.

```
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁', '<unk>']
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=False)
['▁', 'いろは']
>>> sp.encode('abc', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁a', 'b', 'c']
```

In spm_encode CLI tool, we can change the behavior with ``--extra_options=unk``
```
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model --extra_options=unk
▁ <unk>
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model                    
▁ いろは
```

The reason why we do not emit ``<unk>``  by default is that ``<unk>`` will completely loose the information of what sort of input is passed to tokenizer.   It is trivial to rewrite ``<unk>`` from the vocab, while keeping the original information.

issue.title: Batch Processing
issue.body:
Hello!
Is there a way to process batches instead of sentences one by one? Otherwise it is very time consuming.

issue.title: Batch Processing
issue.body:
Hello!
Is there a way to process batches instead of sentences one by one? Otherwise it is very time consuming.

comment.body:
v.0.1.97 supports multi-threaded batch processing. The process is executed in native threads.

```
sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')

with open('large.txt', 'r') as f:
   lines = f.readlines()

ids = sp.encode(lines)   # batch request.
```

issue.title: Treating tabs ('\t') as user defined symbols
issue.body:
I want to use '_sentencepiece_' to try different tokenization approaches for a music representation language (humdrum **kern). It uses the \<TAB\> character ('\t') as a special kind of delimiter, different from any other whitespace character. In order to encode/decode sentences correctly, \<TAB\>s must be preserved.

As far as I know, sentencepiece treats \<TAB\> as any other whitespace, assigning them the '▁' symbol, replacing <TAB>s by whitespaces in the decoded output. I tried using '_spm_train_' with tabs as a user defined symbol, as follows:

```
$ spm_train --input kern_text.krn --model_prefix=kern --user_defined_symbols="$(printf '\011')" 
```

(that's the way I found to specify the \<TAB\> character on the command line)

However, _spm_train_ terminates with an error when trying to save the model:

> sentencepiece_trainer.cc(77) LOG(INFO) Starts training with :
> trainer_spec {
>   input: kern_text.krn
>... 
> trainer_interface.cc(385) LOG(INFO) Loaded all 2057867 sentences
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<unk\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \</s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece:               <--- \\t should be here
> trainer_interface.cc(405) LOG(INFO) Normalizing sentences...
> ...(everything looks ok)...
> trainer_interface.cc(615) LOG(INFO) Saving model: kern.model
> spm_train_main.cc(258) [_status.ok()] Internal: src/trainer_interface.cc(563) [!sp->piece().empty()]
> Program terminated with an unrecoverable error.

This happens for any model type. Using the `--allow_whitespace_only_pieces` option does not help either. Trying other non-control ASCII characters in the 'printf' command works fine.

I'm not sure if I'm doing it correctly, any advice is appreciated.

issue.title: missing __version__ module level attribute
issue.body:
python modules usually have a `__version__` module level attribute. would it be possible to add `__version__` to `sentencepiece`?

for example, this snippet:

```
python -c '
import pyarrow;
import torch;
import transformers;
print("pyarrow:", pyarrow.__version__)
print("torch:", torch.__version__)
print("transformers:", transformers.__version__)
'
```

returns:

```

torch: 1.9.1
transformers: 4.12.3
```

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

comment.body: Fixed this issue in version 0.1.97.

payload.description: Unsupervised text tokenizer for Neural Network-based text generation.

release.name: v0.1.97
release.body:
## Major changes
- Migrated the C++ version from C++11 to C++17. 
- Migrated the CI environment from Travis-CI to Github actions
- Started using cibuildtool to build pypi wheel packages

## New features
- [ALL] Support differential privacy while training.  https://aclanthology.org/2022.findings-acl.171.pdf
-  [ALL] Introduced APIs that return  the struct of ImmutableSentencePieceText, which encodes string-token, id, and utf-8 byte offsets at once.  New API is available both from C++ and Python.
-  [ALL] Allow tab ‘\t’ to be included in user defined symbols. 
-  [ALL] Added NFKD normalization rule.  NFKD rule is provided as a TSV file.
-  [ALL] Added option to emit unknown symbol <unk> instead of raw symbol.
-  [Python]:   Batch encode/decode requests are performed in native multi-threads.
-  [Python]:   Supports to pass a custom log stream during training.
-  [Python]:   Adds module-level version variable:  ``spm.__version__``
-  [Python]:   Creates wheel package of Mac universal binary.

## Bug fixes & minor changes
-  Uses the efficient encoding algorithm by default. Removed the functionality to switch the Viterbi tokenization algorithm.
-  Make the output of Encode and 1-best from NBestEncode same.
- Use std::string_view as much as possible.
-  [Python]  Removed pip package for ppc64le and s390x architecture as cibuiltool doesn’t support them.

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

comment.body:
tf_sentencepiece is already deprecated and no longer supported. The released binary package does not include M2 binary, so this error is expected.

You might be able to build tf_sentencepiece from scratch. This issue might be useful.
https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/367

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

comment.body:
How did you build the binary?  

The cmake configuration will try to make shared library (DLL), but it doesn't work. Better to try a static link.
`
```cmake -A -B ./build -DSPM_BUILD_TEST=ON -DSPM_ENABLE_SHARED=OFF```

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.

pull_request.title: Enable iOS builds
pull_request.body:
This PR allows to build sentencepiece for iOS platforms. To do so just do:
```
mkdir build
cd build 
cmake .. -G Xcode -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../cmake/ios.toolchain.cmake -DPLATFORM=OS64
cmake --build . --config Release
```

issue.title: Bug: can't co-exist with pytorch-lightning
issue.body:
I'm trying to train a T5 model with `transformers` library, which requires the `sentencepiece` library to tokenize sentence. But when I installed it with `pip install sentencepiece`, I can't import the `pytorch-lightning` library anymore. It yields 
* when `sentencepiece==0.1.5`,
```
Python 3.7.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct 26 2021, 06:08:21) 
[GCC 9.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pytorch_lightning
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:58] File already exists in database: google/protobuf/descriptor.proto
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:1401] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
  what():  CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
Aborted (core dumped)
```


* when `sentencepiece==0.1.8`
```
Python 3.7.12 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Oct 26 2021, 06:08:21) 
[GCC 9.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pytorch_lightning
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

I reported the same issue in `pytorch-lightning` [issues](https://github.com/PyTorchLightning/pytorch-lightning/issues/11663).

issue.title: Slow computing time using BPE+Seq2Seq model
issue.body:
Thanks for your excellent work! One thing I would like to check with you is that the model computing time difference between sentencepiece vs. normal tokenization method such as Keras tokenizer. Using a traditional tokenization method, the training time takes maybe 10 minutes. Using BPE, it does not take long to train the text corpus from scratch. However, the modeling time takes appr. 5 hours for one epoch. Did I do anything wrong when combining BPE + seq2seq model? Any comments? Thank you in advance!

comment.body:
The model file is immutable, so we do not support modifying the model after training. However, the model file is just a serialized protobuf so it is technically possible to update the model (adding tokens) manually at-your-own-risk basis.

Please take a look at this thread.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

issue.title: SentencePieceProcessor.encode() breaks down special tokens that exist in vocabulary
issue.body:
Hi,
I am using the t5 sentencepice model:  `gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model`.
The `SentencePieceProcessor.encode()` function does _not_ seem to recognize the special tokens (e.g., `<pad>`,`</s>`), while these tokens do exist in the vocab.


```
gsutil cp gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model /tmp/
```

```python
import sentencepiece as spm
s = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='/tmp/sentencepiece.model')

# Check that EOS exists in the model vocab, get the token corresponding to EOS
s.IdToPiece(s.eos_id())
Out: '</s>'

# Encode EOS string to its id, it doesn't work, breaks it down to smaller pieces
s.encode('</s>')
Out: [3, 2, 87, 7, 3155]

s.IdToPiece([3, 2, 87, 7, 3155])
Out: ['▁', '<unk>', '/', 's', '>']
```

Am I using the wrong function to encode the text into ids?

comment.body: This is a FAQ. https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/667

issue.title: Creating tokenizer from counts file?
issue.body: Is there a way to create the tokenizer from the counts file? This would enable generating a tokenizer from extremely large corpuses feasible as we can use a Hadoop preprocessing step to create the word count statistics. This shouldn't change the correctness because, for languages like English, we don't consider subwords across word boundaries anyways.

issue.title: pkg-config file is broken when CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR is absolute
issue.body:
As per title: `CMakeLists.txt` has
```
set(prefix ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX})
set(exec_prefix "\${prefix}")
set(libdir "\${exec_prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}")
set(includedir "\${prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_INCLUDEDIR}")
```
and so can’t handle absolute paths in `CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR`. This leads to broken .pc files on NixOS in particular.

Identical to https://github.com/libjxl/libjxl/issues/1400 (fixed). See “[Concatenating paths when building pkg-config files](https://github.com/jtojnar/cmake-snips#concatenating-paths-when-building-pkg-config-files)” for a thorough discussion of the problem and a suggested fix, or [KDE’s extra-cmake-modules](https://invent.kde.org/frameworks/extra-cmake-modules/-/blob/master/modules/ECMGeneratePkgConfigFile.cmake#L166) for a simpler approach.

pull_request.title: Sign wheels in GitHub releases
pull_request.body:
Hi,

I'm reaching out on behalf of the [Open Source Security Foundation (openssf.org)](https://openssf.org/). We work on improving the security of critical open source projects like yours. 

Together with [GitHub](https://github.blog/2022-04-07-slsa-3-compliance-with-github-actions/), we designed a free, easy-to-use method of code signing. It will help your users verify that your release wheels were built from your repository’s [workflow](https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/.github/workflows/wheel.yml) and not altered by anyone. It will make your project more secure against third-party tampering and attacks like [Codecov](https://about.codecov.io/apr-2021-post-mortem/) and [CTX](https://sockpuppets.medium.com/how-i-hacked-ctx-and-phpass-modules-656638c6ec5e).

This PR shows how to add this code signing to your workflow. You don’t have to be a cryptography expert or learn complicated tools and [verification](https://github.com/slsa-framework/slsa-verifier/blob/main/README.md#verification-of-provenance) is simple for your users.  

You can read more on the [SLSA blog](https://slsa.dev/blog/2022/06/slsa-github-workflows). Please reach out if you have any questions!

Fixed errors in `sentencepiece_python_module_example.ipynb` notebook: - In 2.0, tf.gfile.* is replaced by tf.io.gfile.*: `tf.io.gfile.GFile` -> `tf**.io**.gfile.GFile` - error during importing `sentencepiece_pb2` - remove redundant imports Tested in colab. "Runtime" -> "Run all" without errors. Also fixed dead links in `README.md` and `doc/experiments.md`.

issue.title: Difficulty installing on M1 mac (solved)
issue.body:
Hi all just wanted to share this in case anyone else runs into it. I was having trouble installing sentencepiece on my M1 mac. Tried `pip install sentencepiece`, tried downloading, tried installing from source. Kept running into:
```  clang -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -Wunreachable-code -fno-common -dynamic -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -isysroot /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX12.sdk -I/Users/jvm/venv/include -I/opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.9/include/python3.9 -c src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx -o build/temp.macosx-12-arm64-cpython-39/src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.o -std=c++11 -mmacosx-version-min=10.9
  src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx:2809:10: fatal error: 'sentencepiece_processor.h' file not found
  #include <sentencepiece_processor.h>
           ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  1 error generated.
  error: command '/usr/bin/clang' failed with exit code 1
  error: subprocess-exited-with-error
```

Tried installing the c library from source, when I tried running `sudo update_dyld_shared_cache` I got a note that it was deprecated, and then couldn't seem to find the header file.

In the end all I needed to do to solve it was `brew install sentencepiece`. So might be ideal to add that to the documentation.

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

comment.body:
We can use '\t' as the constraint of the tokenization, though it is only used in unigram mode.


Here's the sample not using '\t'
```
>> import sentencepiece as spm
>>> with open('botchan.txt', 'r') as f:
...     lines = f.readlines()

>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines), model_prefix='m', vocab_size=2000)
>> .. snip
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁the']
```

Then insert '\t' to the places not to split. ('the' must not be one token')

```
>>> lines2 = [s.replace('the', 't\th\e') for s in lines]
>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines2), model_prefix='m2', vocab_size=2000)
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m2.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁t', 'h', 'e']
```

issue.title: Leftover "▁" characters after spm_decode
issue.body:
After running spm_decode v0.1.86 on the BPE-encoded output of neural machine translation,  special characters "▁" appear connecting some words. I assume that spm_decode should have removed them. Could you please explain why this is occurring and how I can fix it?

example:

before:

`▁The ▁film ▁service ▁calls ▁the ▁film ▁a ▁“ s imp ly ▁kn it ▁com edy ▁of ▁the ▁p ole ▁that ▁shows ▁the ▁un in hib ited ▁ra ge ▁of ▁destruction ▁of ▁children ▁without ▁thought ▁and ▁without ▁a ▁sense ▁of ▁ped agog ical ▁undert ones .”`

after:

`The film service calls the film a “simply▁knit comedy of the pole that shows the uninhibited rage of destruction of children without thought and without a sense of▁pedagogical▁undertones.”`

issue.title: Word based algorithm in SentencePiece is not being able to preserve some character in Devanagiri
issue.body:
The sentence piece provides four algorithm for training the tokenizer. BPE, char, unigram and word. Among these all are performing well however the BLEU score while testing on word based tokenization giving very bad result on test data. This is also the same case with huggingface BertWordPiece tokenizer.

I have tested it on Bodo text which is written in Devanagiri script. I hope this problem will be there in Hindi, Marathi or other Indian languages using Devanagiri scripts.

I have uploaded the tokenizer model file in my page if you need to verify https://github.com/sanjibnarzary/bodo-tokenizers

issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

comment.body:
v0.1.97 adds the option to emit ``<unk>`` instead of the original string.

Here is the example where feeding Japanese characters in English model.

```
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁', '<unk>']
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=False)
['▁', 'いろは']
>>> sp.encode('abc', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁a', 'b', 'c']
```

In spm_encode CLI tool, we can change the behavior with ``--extra_options=unk``
```
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model --extra_options=unk
▁ <unk>
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model                    
▁ いろは
```

The reason why we do not emit ``<unk>``  by default is that ``<unk>`` will completely loose the information of what sort of input is passed to tokenizer.   It is trivial to rewrite ``<unk>`` from the vocab, while keeping the original information.

issue.title: Batch Processing
issue.body:
Hello!
Is there a way to process batches instead of sentences one by one? Otherwise it is very time consuming.

issue.title: Batch Processing
issue.body:
Hello!
Is there a way to process batches instead of sentences one by one? Otherwise it is very time consuming.

comment.body:
v.0.1.97 supports multi-threaded batch processing. The process is executed in native threads.

```
sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')

with open('large.txt', 'r') as f:
   lines = f.readlines()

ids = sp.encode(lines)   # batch request.
```

issue.title: Treating tabs ('\t') as user defined symbols
issue.body:
I want to use '_sentencepiece_' to try different tokenization approaches for a music representation language (humdrum **kern). It uses the \<TAB\> character ('\t') as a special kind of delimiter, different from any other whitespace character. In order to encode/decode sentences correctly, \<TAB\>s must be preserved.

As far as I know, sentencepiece treats \<TAB\> as any other whitespace, assigning them the '▁' symbol, replacing <TAB>s by whitespaces in the decoded output. I tried using '_spm_train_' with tabs as a user defined symbol, as follows:

```
$ spm_train --input kern_text.krn --model_prefix=kern --user_defined_symbols="$(printf '\011')" 
```

(that's the way I found to specify the \<TAB\> character on the command line)

However, _spm_train_ terminates with an error when trying to save the model:

> sentencepiece_trainer.cc(77) LOG(INFO) Starts training with :
> trainer_spec {
>   input: kern_text.krn
>... 
> trainer_interface.cc(385) LOG(INFO) Loaded all 2057867 sentences
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<unk\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \</s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece:               <--- \\t should be here
> trainer_interface.cc(405) LOG(INFO) Normalizing sentences...
> ...(everything looks ok)...
> trainer_interface.cc(615) LOG(INFO) Saving model: kern.model
> spm_train_main.cc(258) [_status.ok()] Internal: src/trainer_interface.cc(563) [!sp->piece().empty()]
> Program terminated with an unrecoverable error.

This happens for any model type. Using the `--allow_whitespace_only_pieces` option does not help either. Trying other non-control ASCII characters in the 'printf' command works fine.

I'm not sure if I'm doing it correctly, any advice is appreciated.

issue.title: missing __version__ module level attribute
issue.body:
python modules usually have a `__version__` module level attribute. would it be possible to add `__version__` to `sentencepiece`?

for example, this snippet:

```
python -c '
import pyarrow;
import torch;
import transformers;
print("pyarrow:", pyarrow.__version__)
print("torch:", torch.__version__)
print("transformers:", transformers.__version__)
'
```

returns:

```
pyarrow: 4.0.1
torch: 1.9.1
transformers: 4.12.3
```

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

comment.body: Fixed this issue in version 0.1.97.

payload.description: Unsupervised text tokenizer for Neural Network-based text generation.

release.name: v0.1.97
release.body:
## Major changes
- Migrated the C++ version from C++11 to C++17. 
- Migrated the CI environment from Travis-CI to Github actions
- Started using cibuildtool to build pypi wheel packages

## New features
- [ALL] Support differential privacy while training.  https://aclanthology.org/2022.findings-acl.171.pdf
-  [ALL] Introduced APIs that return  the struct of ImmutableSentencePieceText, which encodes string-token, id, and utf-8 byte offsets at once.  New API is available both from C++ and Python.
-  [ALL] Allow tab ‘\t’ to be included in user defined symbols. 
-  [ALL] Added NFKD normalization rule.  NFKD rule is provided as a TSV file.
-  [ALL] Added option to emit unknown symbol <unk> instead of raw symbol.
-  [Python]:   Batch encode/decode requests are performed in native multi-threads.
-  [Python]:   Supports to pass a custom log stream during training.
-  [Python]:   Adds module-level version variable:  ``spm.__version__``
-  [Python]:   Creates wheel package of Mac universal binary.

## Bug fixes & minor changes
-  Uses the efficient encoding algorithm by default. Removed the functionality to switch the Viterbi tokenization algorithm.
-  Make the output of Encode and 1-best from NBestEncode same.
- Use std::string_view as much as possible.
-  [Python]  Removed pip package for ppc64le and s390x architecture as cibuiltool doesn’t support them.

New features

  • [ALL]…

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

issue.title: Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" and "？" are not contained in the vocab
issue.body:
I used about 35m Chinese corpus to generate the Chinese vocab, here is my command：
`spm_train --input=test.zh --model_prefix=spm_zh --vocab_size=32000 --character_coverage=1`
but the spm_zh.vocab doesn't contain Chinese full-width punctuation such as "，" ,  "？", "；", "：". Instead, the spm_zh.vocab contains English half-width punctuation such as "," ,  "?", ";", ":". 
In fact, most of the lines in my training corpus use Chinese full-width punctuation but not English half-width punctuation. And Chinese full-width punctuation is different with English half-width punctuation. For example,
`ch = '，'  `
`en = ','  `
`print('ch punc', ch.encode('utf-8')) `
`print('en punc', en.encode('utf-8')) `
`>>ch punc b'\xef\xbc\x8c'`
`>>en punc b','`
I change other Chinese corpus and change vocab_size, however, the problem is still not solved.
Should I set other hyperparameters？

comment.body:
sentencepiece normalizes the input with Unicode NFKC by default, which includes the full/half width punctuations.
You can suppress the normalization with ``--normalization_rule_name=identity``.  We can also define application dependent
normalization rules.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/doc/normalization.md

issue.title: different between command line tool and python with \n
issue.body:
I used two different ways to train a spm,but I find that the result are different.
```python
spm.SentencePieceTrainer.Train(
                                input = '/mnt/tiny.txt',
                                model_prefix='unigram_tiny', 
                                vocab_size=50000, 
                                model_type='unigram', 
                                character_coverage=0.9995, 
                                num_threads=120,
                                train_extremely_large_corpus=True,
                                control_symbols=['[PAD]', '<s>', '</s>', '[SPEAKER1]', '[SPEAKER2]', '[SEP]'],
                                pad_id=0,
                                unk_id=1,
                                bos_id=2,
                                eos_id=3,
                                pad_piece='[PAD]',
                                unk_piece='[UNK]',
                                bos_piece='<s>',
                                eos_piece='</s>',
                                byte_fallback=True,
                                add_dummy_prefix=False,
                                remove_extra_whitespaces=False,
                                user_defined_symbols=['\n', '\t', '\r', '\b'],
                                logstream=open('train-unigram.log', 'w'))```
and command line with :
```bash
spm_train --input=/mnt/tiny.txt --model_prefix ch_unigram_tiny --vocab_size 50000 --character_coverage 0.9995 --model_type unigram --control_symbols [PAD],\<s\>,\</s\>,[SPEAKER1],[SPEAKER2],[SEP] --user_defined_symbols='\n','\t','\r','\b' --pad_id 0 --unk_id 1 --bos_id 2 --eos_id 3 --pad_piece [PAD] --unk_piece [UNK] --bos_piece \<s\> --eos_piece \</s\> --unk_surface [UNK] --byte_fallback --train_extremely_large_corpus true --add_dummy_prefix false --remove_extra_whitespaces false --num_threads 120
```
when use unigram_tiny model,it can tokenize '\n' as a piece of '\n', but use ch_unigram_tiny to tokenize '\n', it return '▁' .
after check the 'vocab', I find the different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16846988/195792264-bab17080-5847-4d05-b05d-522be0d86aae.png)

it looks like command line tool keep a wrong user defined symbol.
so which is right?and if I want to keep '\n', the python way is a good way to go?

comment.body: This is expected.  Unix shell usually handles the escape sequence as-is. i.e., the backslash is parsed as-is.

comment.body:
How did you build the binary?  

The cmake configuration will try to make shared library (DLL), but it doesn't work. Better to try a static link.
`
```cmake -A -B ./build -DSPM_BUILD_TEST=ON -DSPM_ENABLE_SHARED=OFF```

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

issue.title: create sentencepiece from own vocab file
issue.body:
I am very new to using sentencepiece.

I am trying to convert DNA sequences into sentencepiece. My file contains a list of sequences.
For example, two sequences would look like this:
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA
AAACGTGTGTGACCC
...
Using sentencepiece from pretrained English such as test/test_model.model, each DNA letter is considered a word. The ideal case would be to break down each sequence into a sequence of k-mers. For example,
ACTGCACAGTCAGTA consisting of three "words": ACTGC ACAGT CAGTA, if k=5. Is this possible?

It's not clear to me what model_file's are so I am not sure how to convert DNA sequences to sentencepiece. I am using the python module. Right now I am getting `RuntimeError: Internal: src/sentencepiece_processor.cc(891) [model_proto->ParseFromArray(serialized.data(), serialized.size())] `

My goal is to use BigBird in Huggingface, which uses sentencepiece tokenization.

I appreciate your help. Thanks.

comment.body:
We can limit the length of tokens with  ``--max_sentencepiece_length=5``. However, this setting extracts the pieces of length 1..5.

Creating the vocab is not supported. Currently, the model and vocab can only be generated with the trainer and the training data.
However, it is technically possible to manually edit the model file. Please check the previous threads.

comment.body: string_view is the library available from C++17.  Seems that your build environment is old and doesn't support all the features of C++17.  Please upgrade your development environment.

comment.body:

```

pull_request.title: Enable iOS builds
pull_request.body:
This PR allows to build sentencepiece for iOS platforms. To do so just do:
```
mkdir build
cd build 
cmake .. -G Xcode -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../cmake/ios.toolchain.cmake -DPLATFORM=OS64
cmake --build . --config Release
```

issue.body:
I'm trying to train a T5 model with `transformers` library, which requires the `sentencepiece` library to tokenize sentence. But when I installed it with `pip install sentencepiece`, I can't import the `pytorch-lightning` library anymore. It yields 
* when `sentencepiece==0.1.5`,
```

issue.title: Slow computing time using BPE+Seq2Seq model

Thanks for your excellent work! One thing I would like to check with you is that the model computing time difference between sentencepiece vs. normal tokenization method such as Keras tokenizer. https://github.com/Lvby/amazon/blob/master/amazonFood.ipynb

comment.body:
The model file is immutable, so we do not support modifying the model after training. However, the model file is just a serialized protobuf so it is technically possible to update the model (adding tokens) manually at-your-own-risk basis.

Please take a look at this thread.

https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/issues/121

issue.title: SentencePieceProcessor.encode() breaks down special tokens that exist in vocabulary
issue.body:
Hi,
I am using the t5 sentencepice model:  `gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model`.
The `SentencePieceProcessor.encode()` function does _not_ seem to recognize the special tokens (e.g., `<pad>`,`</s>`), while these tokens do exist in the vocab.


```
gsutil cp gs://t5-data/vocabs/cc_all.32000/sentencepiece.model /tmp/
```

```python
import sentencepiece as spm
s = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='/tmp/sentencepiece.model')

# Check that EOS exists in the model vocab, get the token corresponding to EOS
s.IdToPiece(s.eos_id())
Out: '</s>'

# Encode EOS string to its id, it doesn't work, breaks it down to smaller pieces
s.encode('</s>')
Out: [3, 2, 87, 7, 3155]

s.IdToPiece([3, 2, 87, 7, 3155])
Out: ['▁', '<unk>', '/', 's', '>']
```

Am I using the wrong function to encode the text into ids?

issue.title: Creating tokenizer from counts file?
issue.body: Is there a way to create the tokenizer from the counts file? This would enable generating a tokenizer from extremely large corpuses feasible as we can use a Hadoop preprocessing step to create the word count statistics. This shouldn't change the correctness because, for languages like English, we don't consider subwords across word boundaries anyways.

issue.title: pkg-config file is broken when CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR is absolute
issue.body:
As per title: `CMakeLists.txt` has
```
set(prefix ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX})
set(exec_prefix "\${prefix}")
set(libdir "\${exec_prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}")
set(includedir "\${prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_INCLUDEDIR}")
```
and so can’t handle absolute paths in `CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR`. This leads to broken .pc files on NixOS in particular.

Identical to https://github.com/libjxl/libjxl/issues/1400 (fixed). See “[Concatenating paths when building pkg-config files](https://github.com/jtojnar/cmake-snips#concatenating-paths-when-building-pkg-config-files)” for a thorough discussion of the problem and a suggested fix, or [KDE’s extra-cmake-modules](https://invent.kde.org/frameworks/extra-cmake-modules/-/blob/master/modules/ECMGeneratePkgConfigFile.cmake#L166) for a simpler approach.

issue.title: pkg-config file is broken when CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR is absolute
issue.body:
As per title: `CMakeLists.txt` has
```
set(prefix ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX})
set(exec_prefix "\${prefix}")
set(libdir "\${exec_prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}")
set(includedir "\${prefix}/${CMAKE_INSTALL_INCLUDEDIR}")
```
and so can’t handle absolute paths in `CMAKE_INSTALL_{INCLUDE,LIB}DIR`. This leads to broken .pc files on NixOS in particular.

Identical to https://github.com/libjxl/libjxl/issues/1400 (fixed). See “[Concatenating paths when building pkg-config files](https://github.com/jtojnar/cmake-snips#concatenating-paths-when-building-pkg-config-files)” for a thorough discussion of the problem and a suggested fix, or [KDE’s extra-cmake-modules](https://invent.kde.org/frameworks/extra-cmake-modules/-/blob/master/modules/ECMGeneratePkgConfigFile.cmake#L166) for a simpler approach.

comment.body: Fixed in the head.

issue.title: Slow computing time using BPE+Seq2Seq model
issue.body:
Thanks for your excellent work! One thing I would like to check with you is that the model computing time difference between sentencepiece vs. normal tokenization method such as Keras tokenizer. Using a traditional tokenization method, the training time takes maybe 10 minutes. Using BPE, it does not take long to train the text corpus from scratch. However, the modeling time takes appr. 5 hours for one epoch. Did I do anything wrong when combining BPE + seq2seq model? Any comments? Thank you in advance!

You can view my code from the following links:

https://github.com/Lvby/amazon/blob/master/amazonFood.ipynb 
or
https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/Lvby/amazon/blob/master/amazonFood.ipynb

pull_request.title: Sign wheels in GitHub releases
pull_request.body:
Hi,

I'm reaching out on behalf of the [Open Source Security Foundation (openssf.org)](https://openssf.org/). We work on improving the security of critical open source projects like yours. 

Together with [GitHub](https://github.blog/2022-04-07-slsa-3-compliance-with-github-actions/), we designed a free, easy-to-use method of code signing. It will help your users verify that your release wheels were built from your repository’s [workflow](https://github.com/google/sentencepiece/blob/master/.github/workflows/wheel.yml) and not altered by anyone. It will make your project more secure against third-party tampering and attacks like [Codecov](https://about.codecov.io/apr-2021-post-mortem/) and [CTX](https://sockpuppets.medium.com/how-i-hacked-ctx-and-phpass-modules-656638c6ec5e).

This PR shows how to add this code signing to your workflow. You don’t have to be a cryptography expert or learn complicated tools and [verification](https://github.com/slsa-framework/slsa-verifier/blob/main/README.md#verification-of-provenance) is simple for your users.  

You can read more on the [SLSA blog](https://slsa.dev/blog/2022/06/slsa-github-workflows). Please reach out if you have any questions!

issue.title: Difficulty installing on M1 mac (solved)
issue.body:
Hi all just wanted to share this in case anyone else runs into it. I was having trouble installing sentencepiece on my M1 mac. Tried `pip install sentencepiece`, tried downloading, tried installing from source. Kept running into:
```  clang -Wno-unused-result -Wsign-compare -Wunreachable-code -fno-common -dynamic -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -isysroot /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX12.sdk -I/Users/jvm/venv/include -I/opt/homebrew/opt/python@3.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.9/include/python3.9 -c src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx -o build/temp.macosx-12-arm64-cpython-39/src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.o -std=c++11 -mmacosx-version-min=10.9
  src/sentencepiece/sentencepiece_wrap.cxx:2809:10: fatal error: 'sentencepiece_processor.h' file not found
  #include <sentencepiece_processor.h>
           ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  1 error generated.
  error: command '/usr/bin/clang' failed with exit code 1
  error: subprocess-exited-with-error
```

Tried installing the c library from source, when I tried running `sudo update_dyld_shared_cache` I got a note that it was deprecated, and then couldn't seem to find the header file.

In the end all I needed to do to solve it was `brew install sentencepiece`. So might be ideal to add that to the documentation.

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

issue.title: Is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens?
issue.body: Hello, is there any way to prevent the merge of specific tokens, or in other words, prevent specific subwords from being added to the vocab?

comment.body:
We can use '\t' as the constraint of the tokenization, though it is only used in unigram mode.


Here's the sample not using '\t'
```
>> import sentencepiece as spm
>>> with open('botchan.txt', 'r') as f:
...     lines = f.readlines()

>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines), model_prefix='m', vocab_size=2000)
>> .. snip
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁the']
```

Then insert '\t' to the places not to split. ('the' must not be one token')

```
>>> lines2 = [s.replace('the', 't\th\e') for s in lines]
>>> spm.SentencePieceTrainer.train(sentence_iterator=iter(lines2), model_prefix='m2', vocab_size=2000)
>> sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m2.model')
>>> sp.encode('the', out_type=str)
['▁t', 'h', 'e']
```

issue.body:
After running spm_decode v0.1.86 on the BPE-encoded output of neural machine translation,  special characters "▁" appear connecting some words. I assume that spm_decode should have removed them. Could you please explain why this is occurring and how I can fix it?

before:

`▁The ▁film ▁service ▁calls ▁the ▁film ▁a ▁“ s imp ly ▁kn it ▁com edy ▁of ▁the ▁p ole ▁that ▁shows ▁the ▁un in hib ited ▁ra ge ▁of ▁destruction ▁of ▁children ▁without ▁thought ▁and ▁without ▁a ▁sense ▁of ▁ped agog ical ▁undert ones .”`

after:

issue.title: Word based algorithm in SentencePiece is not being able to preserve some character in Devanagiri
issue.body:
The sentence piece provides four algorithm for training the tokenizer. BPE, char, unigram and word. Among these all are performing well however the BLEU score while testing on word based tokenization giving very bad result on test data. This is also the same case with huggingface BertWordPiece tokenizer.

I have tested it on Bodo text which is written in Devanagiri script. I hope this problem will be there in Hindi, Marathi or other Indian languages using Devanagiri scripts.

I have uploaded the tokenizer model file in my page if you need to verify https://github.com/sanjibnarzary/bodo-tokenizers
