issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

issue.title: Serious bug? spm_encode ignores --vocabulary
issue.body:
From the README, I expect that tokens and characters that are not in the model vocabulary should be transformed to `<unk>` when using `spm_encode --vocabulary`:

> spm_encode accepts a --vocabulary and a --vocabulary_threshold option so that spm_encode will only produce symbols which also appear in the vocabulary (with at least some frequency). The background of this feature is described in subword-nmt page.

But it appears that `spm_encode` (0.1.95) ignores the `--vocabulary` option. I have trained a German 10k model, and no matter what text I pass into `spm_encode`, it just outputs it.

First, I generate the vocabulary:
```bash
# Generate the vocabulary
spm_encode --model=spm.model --generate_vocabulary < ../raw/train.de > vocab.de
```

Now, when I run the following, it will output basically any character:

```bash
$ echo 회 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de --vocabulary_threshold 2
▁ 회
```

Here is proof this character is not accidentally in the model:

```bash
$ grep 회 vocab.de
$
```

The vocab looks fine:
```bash
head vocab.de
.       1702696
,       1356060
▁       1202369
s       1059431
en      996857
▁der    908500
▁und    770426
e       723539
▁die    644438
▁in     556034
```

I can also pump Russian through it!

```bash
$ sacrebleu -t wmt20 -l ru-en --echo src | head -n 1 | spm_encode --model spm.model --vocabulary vocab.de
▁ В ▁ ЦАР ▁ три ▁ человека ▁ погибли ▁ при ▁ крушении ▁ вертолета ▁ ООН
$
```

comment.body:
v0.1.97 adds the option to emit ``<unk>`` instead of the original string.

Here is the example where feeding Japanese characters in English model.

```
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁', '<unk>']
>>> sp.encode('いろは', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=False)
['▁', 'いろは']
>>> sp.encode('abc', out_type=str, emit_unk_piece=True)
['▁a', 'b', 'c']
```

In spm_encode CLI tool, we can change the behavior with ``--extra_options=unk``
```
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model --extra_options=unk
▁ <unk>
% echo いろは | ../../build/src/spm_encode --model=test_model.model                    
▁ いろは
```

The reason why we do not emit ``<unk>``  by default is that ``<unk>`` will completely loose the information of what sort of input is passed to tokenizer.   It is trivial to rewrite ``<unk>`` from the vocab, while keeping the original information.

issue.title: Batch Processing
issue.body:
Hello!
Is there a way to process batches instead of sentences one by one? Otherwise it is very time consuming.

comment.body:
v.0.1.97 supports multi-threaded batch processing. The process is executed in native threads.

```
sp = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='m.model')

with open('large.txt', 'r') as f:
   lines = f.readlines()

ids = sp.encode(lines)   # batch request.
```

issue.title: Treating tabs ('\t') as user defined symbols
issue.body:
I want to use '_sentencepiece_' to try different tokenization approaches for a music representation language (humdrum **kern). It uses the \<TAB\> character ('\t') as a special kind of delimiter, different from any other whitespace character. In order to encode/decode sentences correctly, \<TAB\>s must be preserved.

As far as I know, sentencepiece treats \<TAB\> as any other whitespace, assigning them the '▁' symbol, replacing <TAB>s by whitespaces in the decoded output. I tried using '_spm_train_' with tabs as a user defined symbol, as follows:

```
$ spm_train --input kern_text.krn --model_prefix=kern --user_defined_symbols="$(printf '\011')" 
```

(that's the way I found to specify the \<TAB\> character on the command line)

However, _spm_train_ terminates with an error when trying to save the model:

> sentencepiece_trainer.cc(77) LOG(INFO) Starts training with :
> trainer_spec {
>   input: kern_text.krn
>... 
> trainer_interface.cc(385) LOG(INFO) Loaded all 2057867 sentences
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<unk\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \<s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece: \</s\>
> trainer_interface.cc(400) LOG(INFO) Adding meta_piece:               <--- \\t should be here
> trainer_interface.cc(405) LOG(INFO) Normalizing sentences...
> ...(everything looks ok)...
> trainer_interface.cc(615) LOG(INFO) Saving model: kern.model
> spm_train_main.cc(258) [_status.ok()] Internal: src/trainer_interface.cc(563) [!sp->piece().empty()]
> Program terminated with an unrecoverable error.

This happens for any model type. Using the `--allow_whitespace_only_pieces` option does not help either. Trying other non-control ASCII characters in the 'printf' command works fine.

I'm not sure if I'm doing it correctly, any advice is appreciated.

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

issue.title: Encode output does not match 1-best from NBestEncode
issue.body:
I just came across a case where the tokenization from the Encode family of methods doesn't match the 1-best tokenization from the NBestEncode methods. My understanding is that both outputs have identical scores under the unigram model, and that this comes down to different tie-breaking rules when selecting a single output to return. It still seems potentially undesirable, because this can result in situations where different codepaths settle on different conventions (e.g. a potential training vs. inference mismatch)

Repro:

```python
# Download T5 tokenizer
!wget https://huggingface.co/t5-base/resolve/main/spiece.model

# The assertion at the end will fail
import sentencepiece as spm
tokenizer = spm.SentencePieceProcessor(model_file='spiece.model')
text = 'test.........'
print(tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text))  # ['▁test', '........', '.']
print(tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]) # ['▁test', '.', '........']
assert tokenizer.EncodeAsPieces(text) == tokenizer.NBestEncodeAsPieces(text, 1)[0]

comment.body: Fixed this issue in version 0.1.97.

payload.description: Unsupervised text tokenizer for Neural Network-based text generation.

release.name: v0.1.97
release.body:
## Major changes
- Migrated the C++ version from C++11 to C++17. 
- Migrated the CI environment from Travis-CI to Github actions
- Started using cibuildtool to build pypi wheel packages

## New features
- [ALL] Support differential privacy while training.  https://aclanthology.org/2022.findings-acl.171.pdf
-  [ALL] Introduced APIs that return  the struct of ImmutableSentencePieceText, which encodes string-token, id, and utf-8 byte offsets at once.  New API is available both from C++ and Python.
-  [ALL] Allow tab ‘\t’ to be included in user defined symbols. 
-  [ALL] Added NFKD normalization rule.  NFKD rule is provided as a TSV file.
-  [ALL] Added option to emit unknown symbol <unk> instead of raw symbol.
-  [Python]:   Batch encode/decode requests are performed in native multi-threads.
-  [Python]:   Supports to pass a custom log stream during training.
-  [Python]:   Adds module-level version variable:  ``spm.__version__``
-  [Python]:   Creates wheel package of Mac universal binary.

## Bug fixes & minor changes
-  Uses the efficient encoding algorithm by default. Removed the functionality to switch the Viterbi tokenization algorithm.
-  Make the output of Encode and 1-best from NBestEncode same.
- Use std::string_view as much as possible.
-  [Python]  Removed pip package for ppc64le and s390x architecture as cibuiltool doesn’t support them.
